text:
You'll be spending less time in the trenches, and more time elevating your team to do their best, according to their best capabilities. So I'll for sure, spend enough time to get to know the teammates better (unless you already do, which is a great plus).

From then on, I'll make sure that they do enough of what they really like, and they are heard - make it a habit of yourself to meet often and talk about the job, how they feel, and what they want to do. I really liked to keep those casual (no 360s, informal without agendas).

And then, there were the bigger team meetings and demos, where we planned each week's activities in a more structured way. So, even though I didn't have enough time to create lots of actual content, my job was to make everything else easier - creating better SOPs, pushing for learning resources and new ways to implement in the line of work, organizing team activities and mutual contributions, pairing people for tasks, etc.

One more way I saw that helped a lot in making the content team successful (2 years since I left, it's the only marketing team that's actually kept itself together), is making sure that the whole team contributes to the overall team strategy, sure, we've had overall goals given to us by C-level, but then it was up to all of us to come up with activities that will support the goal.

There are multiple ways you can take a team forward. No right and wrong answers. Just have fun in the process, and stay as close as possible to each and every one of them :slightly_smiling_face:

text: TOTALLY what <@UUKNSAKUH> said!!! Management systems are also key, as well as the need to curate their work really fast. I use some nifty tools and systems for that, so please feel free to DM me, and I will share what's in my toolbox of tricks :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Drawing from my own experience in orgs (and then years in management consulting), the most common thing that I see happen, across disciplines, when someone goes from expert IC to IC manager is this sequence of events:
1. Micromanagement, since management is a new skill and you revert to what you know (the weeds of your craft) when you're uncomfortable.
2. Pseudo-burnout with the realization that micromanagement doesn't scale to 5+ people.
3. A swing too far in the other direction: abdication instead of delegation.
4. Careen back and forth a bit from micromanaging to abdication until finding a happy medium.

elements.text: Drawing from my own experience in orgs (and then years in management consulting), the most common thing that I see happen, across disciplines, when someone goes from expert IC to IC manager is this sequence of events:
Micromanagement, since management is a new skill and you revert to what you know (the weeds of your craft) when you're uncomfortable.
Pseudo-burnout with the realization that micromanagement doesn't scale to 5+ people.
A swing too far in the other direction: abdication instead of delegation.
Careen back and forth a bit from micromanaging to abdication until finding a happy medium.

text: This obviously varies by personality and proclivities, but the broad take away is to identify where your behavior lies on the "micromanage -- hands-off" spectrum and make sure that it's a deliberate approach, rather than an instinctive and reflexive one.

elements.text: This obviously varies by personality and proclivities, but the broad take away is to identify where your behavior lies on the "micromanage -- hands-off" spectrum and make sure that it's a deliberate approach, rather than an instinctive and reflexive one.

text: The ICs reporting to you will (1) fail at times and (2) not do things the way you would have done them.  And (2) is _perfectly fine_.  The important thing is to define boundary conditions where you do intervene with their work (e.g. in the content space, maybe it's a certain threshold of negative feedback on pieces of content) and then you let them do their thing within those boundary conditions.

perfectly fine

.  The important thing is to define boundary conditions where you do intervene with their work (e.g. in the content space, maybe it's a certain threshold of negative feedback on pieces of content) and then you let them do their thing within those boundary conditions.

text: All of the above advice is good, but don’t forget the most important step in becoming a manager—listening to your people. Have individual virtual coffee chats, ask them how you can help them achieve their goals, ask them about how they approach content, etc. It’s quite possible, too, that at least one person on this team either wanted the job you landed or wanted someone else to have it. If listening and getting to know your team isn’t your first real act as their manager, it’s going to take a very long time to win them over. Do all the other stuff, too. But start by showing them that you’re there for them.

elements.text: All of the above advice is good, but don’t forget the most important step in becoming a manager—listening to your people. But start by showing them that you’re there for them.

text:
The idea of "wait to build up" is strange to me. The solution here seems to be: stop waiting, get building up!

Like <@U0207Q19V0U> suggested, start shipping articles to Medium. Like, three a week. If you're looking for a gig in writing, and you love writing, producing written content should be easier for you than lesser qualified candidates.

text:
Echoing all the above, and will leave you with something I once heard from a guy who managed an auto body shop:

"I make it clear to my team that they do not work for me. I work for them. My whole job is about their success."

text: I don’t think it hurts to try. I’ve changed industries and even mediums (was a screenwriter for a lot of my life) several times, and samples from different industries (+ showing you’re eager to learn and adapt) worked. Of course, it may be that specific expertise in a certain area is required, but it doesn’t hurt to try and you shouldn’t fear applying, in my opinion.

text:
<@U017WRJTKF1> 100%! I’ve experienced that too. It’s really sad, but it did save me from some toxic workplaces.

On top of having an Arabic surname and being a Woman of Color, I was born in a non-English-speaking country. My mom made sure I grew up bilingual. I studied English for 10+ years, worked as a translator and also taught English by age 18, spent a lot of my life between the US and my home country (also studying abroad), always dived deep into US culture (also have an MA in US-American Studies), and have worked as a writer and editor for plenty of clients — including US companies — for 15+ years. Still, none of that seemed to have _*any*_ value when some companies found out where I was born/which university I attended for my BA. It hurt a lot, but there’s indeed a silver lining…

text:
<@U017WRJTKF1> Thank you! Those experiences got me to a very hopeless point at a time when I was very vulnerable and restructuring my life/moving to a different country, and even made me fork out a lot of money for accent coaching, cause I felt so paranoid. But I’ve learned to embrace and be proud of my story since then. A while ago, I’d never have thought I’d share all of this publicly. :black_heart:

Anyway, didn’t mean to hijack the thread, just hope to help empower the person who posted this question. :hugging_face:

text:
I've been a year out of this sort of role. It sorta depends how fast your company grows / how much capital they have to burn, but if they don’t — and you’re the only marketing person for a while — you’re going to have to get used to doing a lot of different stuff pretty well. 

When I was in this position, I had to do ‘all the content stuff’ — including SEO, thought leadership, random pointless blogs the CEO wanted to publish, product releases, marketing site content, etc — plus run advertising campaigns (SEM + social), create sales collateral and pitch-decks, organise and MC events, arrange sponsorship, create investment decks, full product documentation, manage contract reporting, write internal docs, contribute to strategy, write random emails for people, ghost-write speeches, product micro-copy, PR...

Super-good experience, but also quite... superficial experience.

elements.text:

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"I've been having a bit of a crisis moment for the last year or so and would love to hear thoughts from fellow content marketers! I've been beaten down with toxic culture after toxic culture. When it comes down to it, I really love writing, but my bad experiences are starting to put a bad taste in my mouth and not make it fun anymore. I'm thinking about taking a bit of a break, a few months off to reevaluate what I want to do for a career and take care of my mental and physical health.... but I'm worried there either won't be opportunities/companies in content marketing that will understand my break, or I won't be able to start something totally new because of lack of experience. Thoughts? Tell it to me straight!"

Sorry to hear you’re having a rough time, it’s been a brutal year. If you can afford to take the time off, do it. Don’t wait. Look after yourself. And if I can provide some reassurance: there will be opportunities when you’re ready. Whenever that is. And gaps in resumes will be common, especially when you can just say “I was living through a global pandemic”. And if any hiring manager has a problem with you taking this time off, trust me, you don’t want to work there.

elements.text: Sorry to hear you’re having a rough time, it’s been a brutal year. If you can afford to take the time off, do it. Don’t wait. Look after yourself. And if I can provide some reassurance: there will be opportunities when you’re ready. Whenever that is. And gaps in resumes will be common, especially when you can just say “I was living through a global pandemic”. And if any hiring manager has a problem with you taking this time off, trust me, you don’t want to work there.

text:
What Jon said!

There’s always a risk that a gap would affect you negatively in an interview, but if that’s the case, maybe you’re just up for another toxic environment, so you might as well nip that in the bud.

We put so much effort into presenting our best image in those interviews, that we forget it’s a two-way street — you’re supposed to make sure your true “you” will fit nicely into the team culture and you’ll feel comfortable going to work every day.

Finally, I would say go for that break — nothing is more important than you and your health.
